questions.text: Sixth pharyngeal arch gives rise to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cricoarytenoid The sixth pharyngeal arch gives rise to the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, including the cricoarytenoid muscles. These muscles are responsible for the movement of the vocal cords and are involved in the regulation of the opening and closing of the rima glottidis during speech and breathing. The cricoarytenoid muscles are innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), and develop from the structures derived from the sixth pharyngeal arch. Hence, option C is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Sternohyoid The sternohyoid muscle is derived from the ventral muscle mass of the first pharyngeal arch, not the sixth. It is innervated by the ansa cervicalis (a loop of cervical nerves C1-C3), and its primary function is to depress the hyoid bone. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Cricothyroid The cricothyroid muscle is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch, not the sixth. It is responsible for tightening the vocal cords and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve, CN X). Thus, option B is incorrect. D. Stylopharyngeus The stylopharyngeus muscle is derived from the third pharyngeal arch, not the sixth. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and helps in elevating the pharynx during swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following pharyngeal arch give rise to the development of branchial fistula extending from base of tongue to anterior border of sternocleidomastoid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2nd arch. Explanation: Correct Answer: (B) 2nd arch: The second pharyngeal arch is involved in the development of branchial fistulas. These fistulas occur due to improper obliteration of the second pharyngeal pouch and the second branchial cleft, which should normally fuse during embryonic development. When they do not properly fuse, a branchial fistula forms, which can extend from the base of the tongue to the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. This condition is known as a branchial cleft fistula and is typically associated with abnormalities in the second pharyngeal arch. Incorrect Answers: (A) 1st arch: The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to structures such as the maxilla, mandible, muscles of mastication, and the nerves related to chewing (trigeminal nerve). It is not associated with the development of a branchial fistula. (C) 3rd pouch: The third pharyngeal pouch contributes to the development of the thymus and the inferior parathyroid glands, not a branchial fistula. Therefore, it is not involved in the formation of branchial fistulas. (D) 4th arch: The fourth pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the laryngeal cartilages and muscles of the larynx, along with certain cranial nerves. It does not form a branchial fistula, which is typically associated with the second pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Study the given image,it is congenital abnormality of which of the brachial arch
questions.solution: Correct answer (A) A preauricular sinus or cyst (also known as a "Congenital auricular fistula") is a common congenital malformation characterized by a nodule, dent or dimple located anywhere adjacent to the external ear. They are inherited features and usually appear on one side, but may be bilateral in 25-50% of cases. Preauricular sinuses and cysts result from developmental defects of the first and second branchial arches. Occasionally a preauricular sinus or a cyst can become infected. This and other congenital ear malformations are associated with renal anomalies.

questions.text: A young patient with absent thymus and presented with hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is DiGeorge syndrome. Because thymus and inferior parathyroid arise from third pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: A 67 years old male loses consciousness near the hospital. A physician rushes to the patient and palpates a strong pulse along the inner side of the sternocleidomastoid muscle The vessel palpated by the doctor is a derivative of which of the following aortic arches?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) common carotid artery can be palpated here and it develops from 3rd aortic arch(proximal part)

questions.text: A 52 years old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness following surgery for removal of a thyroid nodule. Which pharyngeal arch is the origin of the nerve most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Recurrent laryngeal nerve which accompanies inferior thyroid artery is injured in this patient. It develops with 6th pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A 45 years old woman is diagnosed with a condition which causes severe pain Near nose and mouth. The involved nerve belongs to which of the following arch?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical history suggests trigeminal neuralgia, which is characterized by extreme pain along the distributions of the maxillary and mandibular subdivisions of the fifth cranial nerve. The trigeminal nerve is derived from the first branchial arch.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is diagnosed with a condition that causes excruciating pain near her nose and mouth. The involved nerve innervates which of the following branchial arches?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical history is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia, which is characterized by extreme pain along the distributions of the maxillary and mandibular subdivisions of the fifth cranial nerve. The trigeminal nerve innervates the first branchial arch. The second branchial arch gives rise to the muscles of facial expression and is innervated by the facial nerve, cranial nerve VII. The third branchial arch is innervated by the ninth cranial nerve, the glossopharyngeal, which innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle. The fourth branchial arch gives rise to most pharyngeal constrictor muscles and is innervated by the tenth cranial nerve, the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has repeated episodes of sore throat and fever. He undergoes surgery to remove collections of lymphoid tissue that lie on each side of the oropharynx between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches. The removed structures developed from which of the following pharyngeal pouches?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The epithelial lining of the second pharyngeal pouch buds into the mesenchyme to form the palatine tonsil. Part of the pouch remains in the adult as the tonsillar fossa. The first pharyngeal pouch develops into the middle ear cavity and eustachian tube. The third pharyngeal pouch develops into the thymus and the inferior parathyroid glands. The fourth pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the superior parathyroid glands. Recall that abnormal development of the third and fourth pouches leads to DiGeorge syndrome and results in hypocalcemia, as well as abnormal cellular immunity and consequent susceptibility to viral and fungal illnesses.

questions.text: The nerve associated with the pharyngeal cleft is derived from-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The nerves from pharyngeal arches and clefts are derived from neural crest cells. Option B-Endoderm forms lining of pharyngeal pouches. Option C-Mesoderm forms substance of pharyngeal arches. Option D-Notochord gives rise to apical ligament of dens and nucleus pulposus.

Correct Answer (D) Option A-Levator palatini is a muscle of palate derived from 4th pharyngeal arch. Option B-Buccinator is a muscle of facial expression derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Option C-Stylohyoid is supplied by facial nerve,hence derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Option D-Anterior belly of digastric is supplied by mandibular nerve,so it is derived from 1st pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A young patient with absent thymus and presented with hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a case of DiGeorge syndrome,in which 3rd pharyngeal pouch is affected [marked as A] ,which gives rise to thymus & inferior parathyroid.Hence,patient presents with absent thymus and hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Option B-B is 4th pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to superior parathyroid gland and C-cells of thyroid. Option C-C is 2nd pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa. Option D-D is 1st pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to auditory tube and middle ear.
